WRITING.TEXT:
The decibel recording was faulty. Anything is super noisy if you record it from that close. The trouble with decibel recording is that there's [no standardized distance](https://www.reddit.com/r/askscience/comments/1me358/is_there_a_standard_distance_for_measuring/) for measuring.
(Use your intuition -- the bags are loud, but not as loud as a diesel grassmower. One of these you can hear very well from a block away, the other you can't.)
Yep. The moment you need to take your burger apart and you're just eating pure patty: you've been sold meatloaf, not a cheeseburger. Meatloaf with a side of bread.

I think it's mostly an analogy for the non-linear storytelling, with the major plotpoints being the larger triangles. It was kind of an off-hand remark in the interview (I think it was with Charlie Rose?) and I wouldn't read too much into it.
I don't think that framing the novel in terms of a Sierpinski Triangle reveals anything that is not otherwise apparent.

Note that the literature may not strictly be *untrue*. That would imply that the inverse of the result is true. I think a better term to use would be *unconfirmed*: most of the results in the scientific literature simply do not have sufficient statistical evidence supporting their theses.

Hey folks, if you're curious about the effects of global warming, you should read *Six Degrees* by Mark Lynas. It's a very accessible book that summarizes the likely effects of one through six degrees of warming.
Good post. This one runs counter to most people's intuitions. If your earnings potential is high, then obviously your time (even before working) is commensurately valuable.

In February 2010 I was investing in niche markets. A friend of mine told me that this Bitcoin thing was pretty cool and maybe I should mine or buy some. The first exchange had just gone live, and Bitcoins were well under a penny each, at the time. I checked it out. Didn't really believe in it because of the scaling difficulties. Never bothered mining or buying any.
This isn't really a mistake or blunder, just a regret. In expected value my decision was probably correct -- if I threw money at every vaguely interesting thing that came along, I would lose all my money pretty quickly. This was just the rare time that the interesting thing ended up being a big deal and I missed out on 100,000x+ returns. However, I should've seen that BTC would probably generate sufficient interest/hype for it to appreciate a little bit.

I did too. Once you suspend your disbelief, there's something really entertaining about how the events in the movie are cast as utterly mundane. The film is funny and ironic, but without being preachy or obsessed with its own cleverness. In a way, that's what's refreshing about it: it's a fairly satirical and self-aware film, but it does not pretend to be *clever*. And because the central premise is that *there is no plot*, it becomes difficult to predict what happens next -- which makes it more exciting to follow the tire around! I was entertained.
I'm surprised nobody has said "travelling" yet. I know people who spent well over half a year backpacking for next to no cost.
The fast answer: economics is not a zero-sum game.
Posting for giveaway!
That's a serious achievement, congrats. On the other hand, I'm pretty sure you can buy those runes for like $3...
Correlation is not causation. I'd steer away from using the word "imply" in this context.

Wow. That website is an awesome tool. It's a shame that the interface is kind of difficult to get used to. With a little bit of polish (I'm thinking of hovertext or annotations on the side), this might make it much easier to read FW.
That's a pretty nice vista!

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else think that pinned repos are not an improvement?
WRITING.TEXT:
Apparently github just rolled out an update that lets you pin any 5 repositories to your profile, instead of showing 5 personal + 5 contributed repositories.
I think the previous interface was better. This new one offers far less information. The long panel for "pinned repositories" also looks kind of awkward, I think.
Wait a second. Since Obama has endorsed Hillary, isn't it reasonable to expect that she will not be indicted? If necessary, Obama could clear her of any wrongdoing by presidential pardon.

The real reason why I advocate siege is because Japanese rely mostly on infantry/archers -- you rarely see Japanese cavalry. And cavalry is of course one of the counters to SO. The other good counter is bombard cannon, which the Japanese don't have.
Teutons would also do well to throw in some siege onagers for area-of-effect against Japanese infantry or archers.
I'm not sure it was a thoughtless mistake -- many outdoors camps leave some doors unlocked, precisely for this reason: in case a lost wanderer needs a place to sleep.
Congratulations on the new lamp shade! It's a nice pattern, if I may say so.
Is it just me or are parts of the video totally frozen? Maybe your recorder couldn't keep up...
If he hasn't been able to rent, sell, or do anything with the property for over 15 years, then I suggest you think about *why* that is... could you be overestimating the demand?

It'd probably be helpful if you were to arrange your buildings to create a forward wall. Throw up a few palisades and the militia rush is no concern. Note that your map was fairly wallable. You should've also begun walling in your villagers (e.g. around gold/wood) when you saw his rush coming so as to minimize idle time.
Was anyone else startled by the density of streetlights on the highway ("Rush Hour" picture)?
As a fun coincidence, it looks as if your painted bean is just about the size of an actual kidney bean.

It's convenient for consumers until there is just one (monopoly) or a few (oligopoly) streaming sites, and then it sucks for consumers.
Beyond that, it's not "better for consumers" in the sense that these streaming sites don't try to actually improve their technology, but just to get exclusive deals that effectively force consumers to use them, as opposed to the competition.
Underrated comment. This kind of exclusive-licensing only encourages anti-competitive behavior.

Imagine this: you take a few days to do your research, invest your $200 as wisely as possible, and manage to get a 100% return in a year, beating most major hedge funds. Congrats, you made $200. Was that worth the **time** invested?

I disagree somewhat. Bitcoin does not have the accessibility or volume to accommodate large-scale capital flight. Thus, I think you're likely overestimating its importance in this scenario. But if China's economy experiences some kind of pullback, then Bitcoin will likely appreciate (I'm just not sure how much).
No, that is not how an investment firm normally acts. This behavior is typical of a parasite losing its host.
Seconded, his books are pretty good and cover a fairly wide area.

WRITING.TITLE: Mayans and Chinese on Real World Maps...
WRITING.TEXT: Chinese and Mayans don't get their additional villagers, but they get their resources taken away nonetheless. This was submitted as a bug report [six months ago](https://www.reddit.com/r/aoe2/comments/3vum05/bug_report_chinese_and_mayans_on_real_world_maps/?) but still hasn't been fixed.
Hahaha. Maybe [this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias) has something to do with it.

Predicting the state and returns of the financial markets over the future decades is difficult to the extent of this kind of article being discardable.
Besides, even if the article were telling the truth: this is mostly a non-actionable insight. How would it change your actions if it were true? Would you try to save *more*? If you're on /r/FI, you're probably already saving as much as reasonably possible.

Buying a NYC apartment is not that bad of an idea -- the real estate market for apartments in Manhattan is likely to stay strong for (at least) another decade, and NYC can offer a great quality of life. Assuming that your acquaintance could afford HOA fees, if applicable, and taxes out of pocket, then that's not a bad situation to be in, even if they have to work in order to cover their lifestyle. I definitely know people for whom this lifestyle would be preferable to, say, using the capital to retire to Minneapolis.
Yes, I'm quite certain that's the [great pacific garbage patch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Pacific_garbage_patch).

To showcase the usefulness of Python even in this kind of scenario, I wrote you a brief script to help choose your next action:
import time print time.strftime("%c") + " is a good time to get a new job!"
True, I don't either! One of the battle scenarios maybe?

For AOK/AOC: 85 if you're Goths, their civ bonus lets you go 10 beyond the pop cap.
Also, technically, you can convert as many enemy units as you like.
But realistically speaking, yes, 75 pop is generally the cap. I don't think that's the case for AOF/AOAK though.

DFW wrote little about the internet. However, much of what he wrote about humans and their relation to media, entertainment, and information seemed to in some way anticipate or subtly address the era created by the internet. Infinite Jest, Pale King, and some of his essays (E Unibus Pluram) are all worth reading in this respect.
That looks *awful*.
